text: uh hi everyone anthony times tano here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new busta
rhymes album
extinction level event 2 the wrath of
god
this is the newest full-length lp from
one of the best
and most eccentric rappers of all time
busta rhymes
i believe this makes his 10th studio
record it's been eight years since his
last
and personally i was curious as to what
he would offer after all these years
especially since this is the sequel to
the original
extinction level event that dropped in
1998 considering the apocalyptic
times we live in currently i guess it
makes sense to bring back
the title but honestly not too much has
changed in busta's creative philosophy
in crafting an album once again he's
asking listeners to bite off more than
they can chew
with 22 tracks that span 78 minutes he's
really crafting albums that have to
bring a little bit of
everything to the table like he's
trapped in the 2000s
the tracks on this thing really do range
in direction
and tone sometimes it's even difficult
to parse out what
busta is exactly getting at on a
particular song because
his bars feature such a chaotic mix of
conspiracy religious mythology
apocalyptic prophecy with some
paranoia and societal critique on the
side
and all of it is broadcast with the
explosivity of
an over budget action flick with a
sci-fi twist
especially on the first leg of the
record where the intro
sounds like a blathering and very
pretentious
start to a movie trailer then you have
chris rocks screaming his brains out and
he pops up at numerous
times to add a little flavor and
personality and levity to the project
though i will say lyrically on this
introductory track
busta is in peak form the rakim feature
on the song is impressive too and
reinforces a lot of the tracks themes
it's a lot to take in but at the very
least busta keeps you on the edge of
your seat and sounds like he hasn't
skipped a beat his flows are still
dizzying his breath control
is godlike and his personality and
expression
are next level the problem is though
busta falls prey to the same pitfall
many flashy and very eccentric rappers
have in the past
and that's the sound and the songwriting
going a little ignored under the
assumption that these strange quirks and
technical skills will be enough to make
up for that gap
for many listeners i'm sure it is and if
you love this record
fine however i can't really ignore just
how underwritten attract like the purge
is
or the completely obnoxious overdubs on
strap yourself down that are very
obviously clipping which is just one of
many
weird mixing blemishes on this project
however this is not as unflattering as
the nonsensical beat switch around the
midpoint of this song
after which nearly everything in the mix
sounds
distorted then there's the song czar
that sticks out for having easily one of
the weirdest
instrumentals on this lp it has this
tense
string swell triplet over a 4 4
with some off beat snares and then some
sporadic piano notes just to add to the
lack of cohesion
it's impressive that busta is able to
deliver over it so
smoothly and aggressively much less find
room for the exuberant gang
vocals of mop but god is it tedious the
the beat the groove gets so
stale so fast and really serves no
purpose other than to be a beat that
no other rapper would rap on while busta
rhymes just
does backflips off of it perfectly while
i do respect the craft i do
in no medium does technical ability
alone reign supreme
ideas and concepts are important too and
if you're working with a subpar idea
doesn't matter how technical you get
with it take out of my mind for example
which in my opinion
is an even tougher listen where busta
rhymes is lyrically
convulsing over the legendary drum break
from bell bib devoes
poison which is somehow more grating
than any death grip song
i've ever heard i think in fact i think
this is how death grip
sounds to people who really hate death
grips
there really is like a lack of balance
and nuance and
subtlety to many of these songs in fact
i think the first
track i really fell in love with on this
one
was the cut featuring old dirty bastard
slow
flow the odb features on this one punch
in really well
and serve as a nice reminder of how him
and busta were two
eccentric kings cut from a strange cloth
the instrumental is as unique as both of
them with these
very odd 8-bit arpeggios
playing out over smooth bass and a dirty
boom-bap beat the flows the delivery the
word play are all colorful of course but
it's reserved enough so that the
madness translates really well the
unsung hero on this track or even the
one featuring rick ross in my opinion
is the ability to restrain furthermore
the ability to edit the ability to
refine which are not strengths that
busta has
in spades across this lp whether that be
on don't go where the q-tip feature just
doesn't really add that much
plus those vocal harmonies there are a
few lines that are very apparently out
of tune
and really could have used a redo then
busta's bars on true indeed
read sort of like a lyrical miracle
jargon with an awkward poop joke at the
very end
then oh no sees busta trying to ride
that low-key
psychedelic trap wave but his voice
totally
man-handles the instrumental to the
point where it makes going in this
direction pointless there's no vibe here
it's like listening to godzilla
violently shake a baby seal you with
anderson pack suffers from a similar
issue i do admit some of pax's
odd production quirks here have grown on
me but the whole thing is just
too subtle too skeletal too off kilter
by the time buster brings his verse on
the back end
it's just way too overpowering too
divergent
but listen for me the record is not a
total wash at the end
we have a lot of great tracks back to
back to back where in my opinion
busta comes off most topically focused
and going into more personal issues
and tying the album up thematically a
little bit at least
seems to draw him a bit more inward
turning down the insanity just a tad and
focusing on the overall tone of these
songs a little more
best i can with rhapsody sees her in
busta exploring narratively
these baby mom baby daddy problems over
a classic soul sample
and hip-hop beat the arguments over each
other and parenting on this one
are petty sure but i think in a lot of
respects very real maybe way too real
meanwhile the cut where i belong with
mariah carey sounds a lot older than i
think it is
it's like a club friendly piece of pop
rap from the 2000s with a
slick r b hook with mariah carey singing
about
messing with the wrong boy the formula
that's being applied here is long
dead at this point but i suppose it's
not a bad resurrection
then on deep thought we have another
concept cut where busta
is in a contemplative mode over his
inner demons whether or not he should
share these feelings with his
significant other specifically
who can sense something is going on and
is trying to draw it out of him
and busta isn't as much rapping on this
track as he is acting in a sense he's
really playing out these
very negative thoughts these positive
thoughts trying to find
honesty with himself and others around
him while also
balance it's once again a super
relatable song that like that cut with
rhapsody
is maybe just too real for words look
over your shoulder with kendrick is sort
of like a victory lap
on the record it was good as a single
it's still good as an album cut
then you will never find another me
features mary j blige who
absolutely stuns love the grand and
classy instrumentation here
along with busta's bold bars that are
pretty reflective
boasting on his legend status his
longevity while also
thinking back to the architects of rap
who he carries the torch for today
very much a last of a dying breed type
anthem which in his case is
absolutely true meanwhile freedom comes
off like a very dark inner monologue
that i think makes
absolute sense for a record like this
and satanic tries to tie
up a lot of the albums apocalyptic
themes societal critiques just bringing
things full
circle with the dark state of the world
that seems to have
inspired this whole project in the first
place and overall it's a very mixed bag
i came out enjoying it generally and
still being
impressed with the incredible amount of
personality and skill that busta
showcases over the years certainly he
was extremely beyond the average back in
his heyday and
that is very much the case now i would
say that's even more apparent now than
ever
but again the issue still remains the
songwriting
is sort of shoddy on this record the
production is very
inconsistent or just bad production or
song concepts going
into these songs from the get-go plus
the fact that the record is so much of a
slog it is really a total beast whose
rough edges could have been
smoothed out for a better result
regardless though i'm feeling a decent
two strong six
on this one tran position have you given
this record a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review next
hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well
over here next to my head is another
video that you should check out
hit that up or the link to subscribe to
the channel anthony fantano
busta rhymes oh forever
